title: Asthma Exercise
content:
####    
Use your reliever inhaler before activity
Many people with asthma now use a single inhaler combining prevent medication with reliever medication. Take 1 or 2 puffs about 15 minutes before exercising.
If you're still using 2 separate inhalers, take 1 or 2 puffs of your[reliever medicine](https://healthify.nz/medicines-a-z/s/salbutamol)[Using a spacer](https://healthify.nz/medicines-a-z/s/spacers "Spacers") increases the effectiveness of[metered dose inhalers (MDIs)](https://healthify.nz/medicines-a-z/i/inhaler-devices).
If you exercise often and you need a dose of reliever before and during your session, ask your healthcare provider to reassess your[preventer medications](https://healthify.nz/medicines-a-z/b/budesonide-inhaler) as you may not yet be on the best possible treatment.

Taking slow deep breaths through your nose with the right breathing pattern can help people with EIA (see below).
####    
Apps reviewed by Healthify
You may find it useful to look at some [Asthma apps](https://healthify.nz/apps/a/asthma-apps) and [Breathing apps](https://healthify.nz/apps/b/breathing-apps).
####  Four steps to good breathing 
#### Breathe through your nose
  * It is important to breathe through your nose as this warms, filters and moistens the air that enters your lungs.
  * It also helps to regulate your breathing.
  * Nose breathing may take practice, especially if you're not used to it.
  * If your nose is blocked by hay fever, dust mite allergy or sinusitis, ask your doctor about nasal treatments.
  * Controlling any allergies and clearing your nose can make a big difference to your daily life and to your asthma.


####    
Use your diaphragm to breathe
Your diaphragm is a large muscle separating your lungs from your abdomen. Your diaphragm can work hard and never get tired.
